newsitem.title: USA: US CREDIT OUTLOOK - Limited pre-payrolls action.
newsitem.headline: US CREDIT OUTLOOK - Limited pre-payrolls action.

text.p: Pre-payrolls nerves should keep price movement limited on Thursday, barring a big shocker in weekly jobless claims figures, economists said.

"Given the fact that Thursday's (claims) number is far away from the payroll survey week it will give you hardly any information at all about Friday's number," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corp.
"It's very very difficult to get much activity so close to the (payrolls) number unless claims are signficantly above or below expectations."
Economists surveyed by Reuters are expecting a slight rise in jobless claims for the week ended August 31 to 335,000 from 331,000 in the previous week.
Claims have risen for four consecutive weeks after reaching a low of 294,000 in late July, while the closely-watched four-week moving average for claims has advanced two weeks in a row.
Economists said claims have probably troughed and are likely to trend even higher in the coming weeks. Therefore, a sizable drop would come as a surprise.

"If we were to get a drop in jobless claims I think it would be important because it's highly unusual at this late stage in the cycle to see claims go lower," said Mary Dennis, senior economist at Merrill Lynch.
"But I would not expect much on Thursday -- if anything maybe a little short-covering ahead of Friday," she added.

Friday's payrolls report will shed more definitive light on third quarter economic strength and could push the Federal Reserve into hiking short-term interest rates at its upcoming September 24 meeting, economists said.
Anticipation of this pivotal release should hamper any major position reshuffling on Thursday.
In addition to the claims report, the tail end of July car sales data will be released as well as individual companies' chain store sales reports for August.
Neither event is likely to produce much price action, economists said.
In late trading on Wednesday, the benchmark 6.75 percent 30-year bond was off 14/32 at 95-23/32 to yield 7.10 percent.
The federal funds rate is expected to open at 5-1/4 percent, in line with the Fed's target rate.
